text: in replyWe find ourselves at an interesting stage in this debate on the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998. I am apparently the last speaker and should sum up. As I understand it, under an agreement that has been reachedMs Macklin-Without either of us knowing.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Without notification to the shadow minister or the minister, some people have negated their right to speak.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Or the Independents.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: You made a very useful contribution and I will come to that in a moment. I am left in the situation where, I understand, the opposition wants to move some amendments which will not be ready for some time. Some discussions are taking place right now and I am sure someone will let me know what is going to happen. In the meantime, I will address the substantive issues that the shadow minister raised during the course of the debate. Thank you to all honourable members who contributed to this debate. The aged care legislation that came to the parliament in October last year saw the implementation of a long negotiated piece of legislation to change the arrangements under which aged care was to be funded in this country. It selfinvolved extensive discussion with the aged care sector--consumers and providers-and it sought to address a fundamental issue for this nation, and that is the increasing number of aged people who are going to require residential care and the capacity of the community to fund it at a level of quality that all Australians can be proud of. We have had many debates in this place and in the broader community about the issue of aged care and I do not intend to canvass those matters today. Some days after I became minister-which was in early October; the new legislation came into effect on 1 October-some substantial issues were raised in the public arena about the policy. I subsequently, following detailed discussions, made some changes, with the support of the cabinet, in November. The nature of those changes was to promote a vision for a secure future for older Austral- illegal. ians in residences. There are a range of matters which that legislation reflected, not the least of which was a change from what was known as an 'accommodation bond' to an 'accommodation charge'. The principle of contribution to the capital cost of care by those who could afford to pay is captured in the legislation to provide a streaming of capital into nursing homes. This is now reflected in the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998, which is now before the chamber, and it is about this matter that the debate over last two days has been pursued. All would agree that the changes that have been made reflect a better approach to the delivery of aged care in this country. I would take the opportunity to thank those in the provider sector and the consumer sector, and indeed the experts in my own department, for the extensive consultation and the extensive work that has gone into making the amendment bill and being able to deliver it to this place. It is not without some differing of opinion. Indeed, the shadow minister addressed those matters but I would assure the House and the previous speaker-the Independent member for Moore, Mr FILING - that the intent of the government is to address these matters on a long-term basis to put in place a funding regime that will sustain, at a higher level of quality, nursing home accommodation for elderly Australians. I would like to refer to some issues of a technical nature that were addressed by the shadow minister. Some of these may be picked up in the amendments that she has been briefly able to tell me about. Whether they actually see the light of day before the chamber right now I am not actually sure, but I would make the point that the shadow minister would not be precluded from moving such amendments in the Senate, so all will not be lost if this bill is now passed. I would indicate to the shadow minister that in such matters I would certainly take account of her amendments when they are finally presented, if not in this place then in the other place. During the course of the shadow minister's contribution yesterday, she asserted that the accommodation charge of up to $12 may be Ms Macklin-Questioned.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Yes, I think you questioned it. Firstly, at the outset I would certainly indicate to you that is not the case. Ms Macklin-Will you indicate why not?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I will indicate that, but I would indicate that it is not in any the way questionable. Apparently the shadow minister based her suggestion on a view that the accommodation charge is, in fact, a type of accommodation bond. The accommodation charge is not an accommodation bond. If it were, it could not be charged to_ people entering nursing home type care because the government has changed the subordinate legislation to cap the level of the accommodation bond. The accommodation charge is an additional amount of resident fees that providers are allowed to charge people entering nursing home type care. Step 5 of the resident fee calculator under section 58-2 of the Aged Care Act, the principal act, makes it clear that additional amounts can be added to the fee provided this is in accordance with the user rights principles. Subparagraph 58-1 (a)(ii) of the Aged Care Act provides for additional fees to be set out in the user rights principles. This is where the accommodation charge has been provided for with a maximum of $12 a day. The user rights principles are subordinate legislation under the Aged Care Act and these principles were amended and gazetted on 16 November, coming into effect on that day, to provide for an additional amount of up to $12 per day where someone was entering nursing home type care. If I recall correctly, that amendment was gazetted on the day that I made the announcement. The member for Jagajaga may not have understood the meaning of the relevant section of the user rights principles. The relevant section is 23-8(3)(a) headed 'Cap bond amount to be taken into account'. The reason for this heading is that this additional fee, the accommodation charge, is .allowed only for people who have had their accommodation bonds capped under the user. rights principles-that is, people who are entering residential care at nursing home level. I think that Ms Macklin would be aware that the headings do not form part of the legislation and are used as' a guide only. The member also suggested that paragraph 57A-2(1)(a)(ii) allowed people to gain access not through the ACAT assessment but through ability to pay. Indeed, I was listening to her speech and I heard that reference made, and I would assure the shadow minister that that is not true. Anyone entering a nursing home or hostel must-I stress 'must' - be approved by an ACAT before any subsidy can be paid. It is a precondition of entry into either of services. Section 21 of the Aged Care Act makes this clear, and no amendment is proposed to this in the Aged Care Amend\TIent Bill. So the gatekeeping role of the ACAT is absolutely, essential and there is no capacity to avoid that gatekeeping role; and I am sure the shadow minister will be pleased to have that point clarified. The paragraph that the member refers to relates to the very limited circumstances where an ACAT cannot determine whether nursing home or hostel care is most appropriate, and that happens on occasion. For example, this will occur where a person's care needs are very unstable or where they are on a borderline between the two types. In these cases the type of accommodation payment is left open for agreement between the resident and the provider, and what is paid will probably depend on the type of facility the resident prefers to enter. I do not have the actual numbers but I understand a very small number of people fall into that category. The member also indicated that the government intended to increase the level of accommodation charge without reference to parliament. This is certainly not true. The cap on the 1evel of the accommodation charge is set at $12 and there is no intention to increase this amount. There must obviously be some mechanism for change to take account of inflation over time, just as we have seen recently with the increase in age pensions. We must be able to take account of movement in prices. The rate must be set out in the subordinate legislation and this must be tabled in both houses and is subject to parliamentary disallowance. The reason is that these are substantial issues and, in a democracy, having a system' of parliamentary scrutiny and a disallowance system is a fundamental commitment of the executive to enable the public, through its representatives, to see changes in charges. I would reiterate that point for the benefit of the shadow minister and assure her that there is no intent to be able to vary those fees other than in the way and in the circumstances that I have described. The member also asked for 'nursing care' the to be defined. It is the commonly understood definition. It has been used for very many years in the National Health Act with no difficulty whatsoever. ACATs are very familiar with the term and they are the ones who will determine whether a person has a continuing need for nursing care or not. Accepting the pivotal role that registered nurses and others perform who are on ACAT teams gives definition to the term 'nursing care'. With those few remarks, I again thank members for their contributions. I have here a late message from my sponsor. Mr Fitzgibbon-Doug Moran!

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I was thinking it was the whip, actually. I understand that detailed amendments will be moved. We will wait for the actual printout of those and then shadow minister will proceed to deal with her amendments. I might say to the shadow minister that I have not had an opportunity to look at the detailed amendments, but I indicate that from the brief look that I have had at them-and responding in the way that I have to your earlier concerns which I understand your amendments reflect in the main-it would not be possible for the government to support those amendments. We would like the bill to stand as it has been presented to the House. We will give consideration to your amendments, which I have no doubt will be moved in the other place. I am keen for this amendment bill which gives effect to decisions in November to pass through the House of Representatives and move to the Senate. I therefore commend the amendment bill to the chamber. Finally, I indicate to the shadow minister that I may be called away from the chamber for a short period. I am not sure how long the consideration of amendments in detail will take. If I do have to leave the chamber, I apologise to the shadow minister. Mr FITZGmBON (Hunter) (12.50 p.m.}-I would like to commence my contribution to the consideration in detail stage of the Aged Care Amendment Bill by expressing my outrage for having been denied the opportunity to speak in the second reading debate. I believe that this is one of the most critical bills ever considered by this House and the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) is scurrying out of the chamber. I remind the House that this bill amends the government's own Aged Care Act 1997-the act which introduced the now infamous and universally condemned entry tax for nursing homes. The former Minister for Family Services, the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), came into the House day after day during question time and unsuccessfully attempted to justify that entry tax. Thankfully, after a period, we did have a backflip. The bill we are debating today deals with the backflip. It pulls the backflip into place. Mr MCClelland-A triple backflip!

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: PAIRS
text: Indeed it was. Today we are considering a bill-which the minister is not prepared to stick around for-that apologises for kicking pensioners in the ribs, but then it kicks them in the other side. It apologises for beating up on older Australians and makes amends by whacking them across the face with the introduction of an annual charge. In my two years in this parliament I have not seen a piece of legislation cause so much angst in my local community as did the government's Aged Care Act, with its accompanying entry tax and, of course, its extra daily fee. The minister told us, in his introduction to the new bill we are considering today, that the bill is in response to issues raised by some older Australians. The minister must have a funny electorate, very different to my own. In the last 12 months my office has been inundated with letters, petitions, phone calls and visits from older Australians and their families, concerned about the impact of that original act. The minister wants us to believe that this is only a finetuning of what he believes to be an appropriate piece of legislation. To me, that is extraordinary. We have had the backflip, but the impact of the original legislation has not moved on. There are still older Australians out there who are confused about where they stand with respect to the entry tax and there are still care facilities bearing the costs of the original proposals. I want to share with the House a copy of a letter written in December of last year by Mr Bob Russell to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Mr Russell is the General Manager of the Upper Hunter Village Association, which is in my electorate. In his letter, he said: My dear Prime Minister, Please find enclosed an account I have received from our Solicitor for the preparation of "Nursing Home", "Hostel" and Accommodation Bond Agreements. These contracts, as you are fully aware, are now little more than scrap paper. Therefore we believe that it is more than reasonable to expect reimbursement for. the attached account. I also assume that as a gesture of goodwill you will try to send us your cheque prior to Christmas. The cheque should be made out for $2902.40 and made payable to Upper Hunter Village Association Ltd. I thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding in this matter. Bob Russell is a great bloke and a competent manager, but how misguided his faith in the Prime Minister was. He has now found it necessary to write to the Prime Minister once again. The letter is dated 9 February and he says: I refer to my letter regarding reimbursement of Solicitor's fees, dated 2nd December. It appears that you may have misplaced my letter, or Treasury has been a tad slow in processing it because you see I still have not received a cheque for $2,902.40. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: PAIRS
text: Corio) (12.55 p.m.)Like the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), I am not happy that the government's threat to guillotine this aged care debate has prevented me from raising in detail the concerns of many of my older constituents in Corio who are angry and disgusted at the policy shambles now evident in aged care in this country. The Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 gives effect to the tortuous set of changes made to the original June 1997 bill presented by the government. Members will recall that at that time the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) proudly aged announced that his policy introducing accommodation bonds was set in concrete. The Prime Minister denied that older Australians would have to sell their family home to pay for the accommodation bond. It was only after the Labor opposition and the aged care sector turned the blowtorch on the Prime Minister that he withdrew that obnoxious provision. This bill gi ves effect to the latest government changes. It introduces an accommodation charge of up to $4,380 per year or $12 per day for those with assets over $44,400. The assets test will include the family home and, as 70 per cent of aged pensioners have only one asset and that is the family home, most will be affected by this charge. The bill also introduces new daily fees for new residents, who will have their income tested to assess their liability. Part-pensioners and self-funded retirees will be affected by this measure. The extra daily fee is set at 25 cents of every dollar over. $50 per week of private income they earn-not counting the pension-up to a maximum fee of $36.90 per day or $258.30 per week. It should be clearly understood that the money from this additional daily fee goes directly to government revenue and constitutes another tax on the aged. The aged care bill we are debating in this House today is an indictment of the failure of the Howard government to master the policy process in an area of critical policy affecting the lives of older Australians. Chaos and confusion reign in the aged care sector t9day. Older Australians are confused and angry at the myriad changes made to the government's policy since it was first announced in 1997. They are also angry at this new Howard government tax on the aged in this country. Church and community aged care providers have continually criticised the government for the aged care mess it has created. Only yesterday at a national meeting organised by the Uniting Church, the welfare sector called on the government to institute a specific capital funding program and called for extra funding to support expanding needs in the home and community care area. Perhaps the greatest condemnation came from the welfare sector in its press release issued on 24 March, when it said: Six months since the introduction of the government's aged care reforms, there is still massive confusion and uncertainty among residents, carers and families. The aged in Australia have borne the brunt of Treasurer Costello's cruel spending cuts. John Howard and Peter Costello have ripped some $500 million from aged care in their first budget, and Geelong's aged are now suffering. While the Treasurer protects the tax rorters by failing to move on the use of family trusts to minimise income tax, he drives the boot into the aged of Australia with a whole series of budget measures that attack their income base and their lifestyle. It does not stop with the nursing home changes that are the subject of debate in this House today. We have seen an increase in nursing home fees. We have also seen the axing of the Commonwealth dental scheme. We have seen cutbacks to essential medicines and to hearing services and we have seen increased charges for home and community care in this country. Now the aged are staring in the face a goods and services tax that will really penalise them In my own electorate, the great public aged care facility, the Grace MCKellar Centre, registered an annual loss of $826,000 in 199697 in its annual report. I put on the public record that state government funding .cuts totalling $750,000 and Commonwealth funding cuts of $221,000 are responsible for that. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: PAIRS
text: Barton) (1.00 p.m.)At the outset I would like to indicate-and I get some joy in doing so-that, last night in the course of my speech, I received an interjection from the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and another government member saying that a statement. I made was wrong. The statement. I made was that there is now a two-year waiting period for a carer before the home is exempt from the means test, but that carer must be on' a pension. That was conceded by government members. I also said that a close relative-I understand a close relative, for instance, includes a grandchildmust be in the home for five years but that, as an additional qualification, he or she must also be a pension recipient. That was disputed by way of vigorous interjection. I have since gone back to the bill and I refer the honourable member for Bradfield to subparagraph 44-7(l)(b)(ii) which says: . . . a close relation of the the home for the past 5 years and, at the entry time, was eligible to receive an income support paymentThat is, a pension or a part pension. So I was right and the member for Bradfield was wrong. The government members should look at what they are talking about. What this government has done to the aged care sector is disgusting. There is no other word for it. It has taken money out of the sector. It wants money to come into the sector via hitting the senior citizens who need the service-hence, its description of the userpays principle. It has taken $500 million out of the sector, and what is going in is not going to be enough to satisfy the capital needs of the nursing homes. In saying that, I am not advocating that the user-pays principle be applied. I think this is a matter for the whole community because the whole community has a responsibility for caring for our senior citizens. By way of demonstrating the point as to what has occurred, I asked the former Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, a question on notice, on 13 May 1997: Do parts VAB and VAC of the National Health Act provide for payment of additional recurrent funding for upgrading, rebuilding or erection of new nursing home premises. And the answer was yes. Those parts were, of course, the initiatives of the former Labor government and the minister conceded that they provided for the capital improvement and creation of nursing homes. Then I asked: Is she able to say whether the payments were introduced by the Govemmentthat is, the former Labor governmentin recognition of the need to provide special funding for upgrading of nursing home premises. And the answer was an emphatic yes. So the minister conceded the rationale, the reasoning and the purpose of the former Labor government's provisions to upgrade and improve the much needed capital infrastructure of nursing homes. I also asked what was going to happen to the joint funding arrangements that the Labor government had initiated as a result of the Liberal government changing its regime. This is what the minister had person who had occupied to say: Under the new Aged Care Bill 1997, a service may receive certification to charge accommodation bonds if it meets certain building and care standards. To receive certification, any outstanding additional recurrent funding would need to be relinquished. The minister was saying that, to receive the entitlement to charge the bond that was being introduced and to get the benefit of that intended capital flow under the mark 1 aged care amendments, the nursing homes had to relinquish parts VAB and VAC of the National Health Act-the joint funding arrangement payments. And that is what happened: Nursing homes relinquished the funding arrangements they had in place. In many instances, they had contracts with builders and so forth to develop the capital infrastructure of the nursing homes. And what happened? The minister said, 'If you want to enter into the brave new world, into the new regime-the bond regime-you've got to abandon those capital projects.' These capital projects were worth literally hundreds of thousands of dollars in the case of very many nursing homes. And what has happened? The government has pulled the brave new world away. It is not such a brave new world; it is a horribly muddled, a confused and a cowardly, discriminatory world for senior citizens. As a result of this government's complete ineptitude, nursing homes have been deprived of funds-they have been specifically required by the government to relinquish their capital funding. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: PAIRS
text: --The Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 and the amendments that we are debating today give a most graphic demonstration of two things: firstly, the incompetence of this government and, secondly, how not to conduct public policy making in social policy. This is how not to do it. If someone thinks this is accidental, it is not; it is symptomatic. Let us go back to the previous conservative government. Remember Medicare? How many versions did we have of Medicare-nine versions in seven years or something similar? We are up to about version three of fee structures for nursing homes. We said at the start that the up-front fees would not work. We have said that since day one. I am saying here and now that this will not work either. This does not solve the problem; it just creates a set of new ones. I also make another prediction: it will be changed again, and guess what is going to happen? The aged of Australia will be told, 'Vote for us to sell Telstra and we'll put money into nursing homes.' You watch, that will be the pay-off. The problems being caused in nursing homes will be used as an incentive to sell Telstra in order to get some money to put back in. That is absolutely guaranteed. There is no doubt that that is what is lined up---create chaos and then try to find a quick fix which solves some ideological problem. The tragedy is that the Australian people are very good at public policy making. We have coherent, sensible public debates on a range of issues, and we have done' over a number of years. We have a society which is mature and which is caring. If well led,· its members will take hard decisions. They will go with governments that give leadership and give them respect for their points of view. What they do not want are announcements out of nowhere, with no policy underpinning them, simply aimed at cutting half a billion dollars out of an area such as residential aged care. But that is what they got-bad process, bad policy, bad politics. The reaction following on from that was to blame everybody else-blame us for scaremongering; blame pensioners for squatting in hospitals, as put forward by Doug Moran; blame somebody else, Eventually, the government has been forced to face reality and is being dragged, kicking and screaming, to amendments which it knows will not work. We all service our constituents, We all have nursing homes in our electorates. All our electorates contain families with a member or members requiring nursing home care. All of us, government as well as opposition members, are being approached by nursing homes saying, 'We're in trouble. It doesn't work. What do we do next? What's going to happen next? How can it be fixed?' And people are coming to us saying, 'What do we do?' I have had a number of these cases in recent weeks. In one case, the person died-and I think the family were so grateful he died, because they were absolutely despairing; they did not know what to do. They rang a number of nursing homes for a solution just to have the nursing homes say to them, 'We don't know.' The legislation currently in force is for upfront fees. The government has announced some changes-but God knows when they will happen! What is more, the government has just changed the dates, it has changed the amounts and it has changed the assessment instruments. We do not know what is happening. Why would a government create such chaos? The fact is that the government cannot help itself; that is why. It is symptomatic of its incompetence. No'-one sets out to cause chaos deliberately-perhaps some may, but governments do not do that. This is just symptomatic. This government is judged and marked on this one issue to be a disgrace. This is not about nursing homes. This is about finance; it is about cutting half a billion dollars out of a budget off the backs of the aged and their families-all tb,at nonsense. I have listened with interest to remarks about how the Labor government reduced nursing home subsidies. The fact is that there was enough there to cut half a billion dollars out, wasn't there. There Was enough there to save half a billion dollars. We left you that much in the forward estimates and the budgets to enable you to save that much. How dare you suggest that somehow it is our fault. How dare you try to blame us for your own ineptitude. (Time expired) I

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: PAIRS
text: Barton) (1.10 p.m.)In again opposing the second and third readings of the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998, I note that'the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) in his summary of the debate said that the government's principle was to introduce a system where those who could afford to pay paid and made their contribution, and that those funds went into the capital needs--or words to that effect-:-<>f nursing homes. If you look at what the government has on the table, it is a proposal whereby anyone whose assets exceed the $44,000 assets test will be required to pay $4,380 accommodation charge. That applies across the board. As soon as anyone jumps over the $44,000 cliff, they have to dish out. So there is no sense of equity or capacity to meet the fee in there; that hits everyone. if someone's assets are $44,005, they still to pay. So it is wrong to say this is falling on those who have a capacity to meet the fee. In most cases, the principal asset-just about the only asset-of senior citizens at that stage of life is going to be their home and, course, some of the furnishings they will have within it. So they are going to have to pay. They are going to have to either find some alternative source of funding or sell their homes. But I suppose it is arguable, in the minister's reasoning, to say that the daily structure that he is implementing, or proposes to implement, with this bill falls more heavily on those who have a greater source of income. That is at least arguable. That, of course, applies where someone earns $50 more than the pension; for every dollar that they earn above that amount, a quarter of it goes into this daily fee. Again, it is arguable that that burden falls more heavily onto those who have a higher income stream. But the minister is quite wrong in saying, as he went back to his rationale, that the burden falling on those have a higher income stream is then going to be applied to upgrading the capital of the nursing homes. I say that because we have seen from our side of the debate that that is not happening at all. This accommodation charge is not going into the capital structure, capital improvements, of the nursing homes; it is going into government coffers. I was disappointed that the minister address that issue which we emphatically have said was the case. Indeed, we have challenged the minister to say that he has given false information to the House in stating that that accommodation charge is going into nursing home capital. It is not. The nursing homes themselves say that it is not going into their capital improvement. So the minister is quite wrong in his fundamental premise for this bill-his fundamental the premise being that he has said the burden is falling on those who can pay, and that burden is being put into additional funding for nursing homes. That is not right. The burden is hitting everyone as soon as they fall over the Even $44,000 cliff. And, in so far as there is a means test criterion applied, that criterion is simply being used as an additional tax measure. There is no question that it is a tax in all but name only. One would think we were talking about of people of substantial means in this discussion; we are not talking about such people at all. Fifty dollars a week over a pension equates to about $2,500. Any person who earns money over $2,500 and is faced with this situation of going into a nursing home loses a quarter of fee it. For instance, if we are talking about an income of $7,500 over that pension amountwhich is a meagre amount; often it is topped up by superannuation-that person is going to lose a quarter of it. It is a meagre income to start with. The government just has not realised, or if it has it has ignored, the extent of hardship that this is going to create for people of very, very meagre means. Again, the government is quite wrong to suggest that those people can afford to pay. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: PAIRS
text: As I was saying earlier, we in this who country have had a decent process, a good process for public policy making. Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the parliamentary committee report on the home and community care (HAeC) program, Home but not alone. This report canvassed the need for us to integrate our aged support programs, whether they be in a person's home or in a nursing home, together with post-acute problems, and the need to synchronise and make did not complementary all those programs. There is a real need in this country, with its ageing population and the increase in dementia. We are all very aware of those issues. The community is very aware of them. We all live in our community. We all live in communities with families that have family members who are now, or will be, in need of some kind of support. What this country needed from this government was an approach which would allow the community to understand the issues, to recognise that demands are being made and to canvass options to fairly share the burdens. That is what we needed. That is how you develop public policy. That is how you bring things forward. What we have instead is a budget announcement of a cut of $lh billion from residential aged care, a cut of $80 million from the home and community care program as well as user pays of 20 per cen-. Think of what that means in terms of things such as volunteer programs. You would pay a volunteer to come and visit you. How do you have user pays with volunteer programs? None of this was thought through; none of it was brought into the community and canvassed and developed. That is more than an insult; it is so very disrespectful and destructive. The damage that has been done to public policy making is untold. Add to that the defunding of the Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, which is one of the key bodies that has helped us as a parliament and in government to consult with our community and to work through issues and policies-the taking away of their funds so that they can no longer contribute. The removal of support to a range of peak bodies in the welfare and community sectors has all been aimed at removing voices. In other words, this government does not want debate, it does not want discussion and it does not want a dialogue with its own community. It wants to issue edicts and make announcements which have nothing to do with policy. Then the government tries to somehow fill in behind. We have watched government speaker after speaker somehow try to justify that all these measures were about improving standards. The minister may well be able to clarify it and tell the parliament and the people of Australia how much money has been raised to compensate for the cuts in the budget to date. How far behind is the sector in terms of moneys raised by its initiatives which have been removed by budget cuts? What is the balance? The message that the government is trying to give to the community is-and this is what the government backbencher who was speaking was saying-that this is going to give extra resources; this is going to improve the standards. The fact is that we know that it is the opposite; we know that standards are being reduced, because there is less money available. The government has cut $500 million out and the nursing home sector cannot pick it up, so it is actually behind. The extra fees being charged are not for nursing homes; they are for the government. This pretence that somehow this is all about improving standards is an absolute deceit; it is deceitful, it is dishonest and it is disgraceful. It really is important that the government comes clean and gives an accounting of the funds saved to date and the funds raised to date. On that measurement, I have no doubt that the nursing home sector would be delighted to be advised of how much better off they are. Nursing homes are one part of the sector. We have had a government member speaking as though hostels and nursing homes are identical. They know that is not true, as do we, the aged and their families. Nursing homes relate to hospitals, not hostels. So the deceit being practised in this place by using a system for hostels as though they were nursing homes is absolutely dishonest-totally dishonest. We need to integrate home and community care and support programs, postacute care, nursing home care and hostel care; they need to be part of an integrated holistic approach for the support of our people-our frail aged and disabled. This is not. (Time expired)

Before starting to go through the amendments, I would like to put on record my thanks to my staff and to the clerks for getting these amendments together so quickly. This is an area where we have had considerable debate over the last 18 months and we are still here today, trying to clean up an act and the Aged Care Amendment Bill which is before us. It is still a mess. Nevertheless, we will try, through these amendments, to make some improvements to it. Some suggestion has been made by some government speakers that this issue is really not of any great interest any more to the elderly in this country. I would just draw the government's attention to a media release that, in fact, was put out yesterday by the main welfare groups-ACOSS, the Salvation Army, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation-headed 'Welfare sector calls for urgent action on aged care'. As stated in this press release: The Aged Care Amendment Bill is currently before the parliament. The opportunity still exists to redirect its focus. Six months since the introduction of the government's aged care reforms, there is still massive confusion and uncertainty among residents, carers and families. It goes on to say: It is impossible to remove hundreds of millions of dollars from the aged care system without a drop in the levels of care to which ageing Australians are entitled. This press release sums up the enormous concern that exists in this community about what this government is doing to the elderly-the enormous concern that exists all around this country. We will try again today to remove some of the most iniquitous parts of the changes that this government is trying to impose on the elderly in this country. If the government does not see fit to support our attempting to do so here in the House today, I very much hope that the other parties in the Senate and the Independents do so. That then will enable us to have a return to a fairer and more equitable system of aged care in this country. I will just go through the purpose of the amendments that are before the House today. We are trying to achieve a number of things. The first is that we are seeking, by these amendments, to remove all reference to the accommodation charge. The Labor Party has made it very clear that we do not, and will not, support charging fees to people who need nursing home care. One of the critical differences between the Labor Party and this Howard government is that, as far as we are concerned, nursing home care is not a matter of choice. Nursing home care is sought by people when they must have intensive nursing care. It is not an accommodation choice, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) likes to say to people. It is something that happens when someone might have had a stroke or when some other disastrous health change has occurred and they need to go into a nursing home. What we do not want to see in Australia is that charges are put in the way of people receiving essential nursing home care. We on the Labor side of the House know, through our experience over the last 20 years of this government's opposition to Medicare, that this government-this coalition of Liberal and National parties-does not understand what it means to have free and universal access to health care. We see that again today in this bill that is before us. This government does not see that there is anything wrong with charging people $4,380 to stay in a nursing home, for every year they are going to be there, for up to a maximum of five years. This government does not see anything wrong with charging nearly $22,000 if you need to go into a nursing home. What, of course, has resulted already since this government introduced this charge is that people are saying, 'We can't pay this fee, so we are either going to stay in hospital, because we have had to go-' (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: PAIRS
text: The amendments before the House-whilst no-one would deny some of the substance of what the opposition is saying today-are precipitated by the fundamental issue that it is $40,000 a year to keep these people in these homes and, within about 15 years, we will have about one million people in that category, which is $40,000 million off a budget of $100,000 million. So, clearly, the problem here is enormous. If we roll the clock back to 1972-and the honourable member who comes from Tasmania who at present is representing the government on the front bench, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), will agree with me very strongly when I say this-and look at the 20 or 30 years prior to that, the population of Australia doubled in that period of time. If, in fact, the population Australia were to double over the next 20 or 30 years, we could easily accommodate this problem because there would be a lot of young people in our community working and paying taxes, and those taxes would be able to handle the problem that is arising here. However, we have an ageing population and we have the sorts of social attitudes that constantly come from the opposition benches-many of those attitudes being created by the opposition benches with respect to family law and family life in Australia-and the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) would be one of the great exponents of the sorts of attitudes which have resulted in women now feeling ashamed to be mothers, so we simply do not have a population. In fact, the population of Australia this time next century will be 12 million people, that is all. They are not my figures; they are the figures of Professor Richard Blandy in a landmark article in the Australian newspaper last year. I went up to the library, because I was quite astounded by this fact, and found out that, yes, on the demographic trends at the present time, that most certainly will be the case: there will only be 12 million Australians. We are, in fact, a vanishing race, and vanishing at a very fast rate. So that is the base reason. But coming back specifically to the amendments being moved, I am finding that with nursing homes the change in categories is taking avery, very serious bite. For example, I asked the Tully nursing home, 'What are the changes that are involved?' And they told me, 'Well, we are in the process of reclassifying.' I then said, 'How does that affect you?' And they said, 'Well, a lot of our people cannot be reclassified up to the higher classification; in fact, they have to be classified downwards into a lower classification.' Whilst a lot of nursing homes in Australia. I do not think are playing the game honestly and fairly in the way the Tully nursing home is, I must say that a number of the nursing homes in North Queensland certainly are, and they are taking very real and substantial pain. Tully nursing home is a nursing home of a moderate size; I might even say that, size wise, it is on the lower end of the spectrum. It is a very beautiful facility. But the change in categories is costing it $50,000 a year. So it has played the game. It has had to downgrade an awful lot of its people. , What is happening in the bigger city based nursing homes-which appertains to the amendments that are being moved-is that they are shuffling out the patients. This is a very easy thing to do in the big cities with a big turnover of patients: those nursing homes simply replace category 4 patients with category 2 patients and, therefore, are able to keep their incomes up. That is not an option that is available to the smaller nursing homes. They cannot achieve a turnover anywhere near as quickly and replace those people with bigger revenue earning-as far as the government funding system is concerned-type patients. It is a very serious issue to suddenly find a deficiency of $50,000 or $60,000 a year in nursing homes the size of the Tully nursing home. I pay very great tribute to those people who run that nursing home- Mr Collins, Mr Bryson, the head nurse and the various other people. But this place must acknowledge the very real problems they have in replacing their assets, as every speaker in this place has made reference to. If the proposals being put forward are cut off, clearly there will be a great problem in replacing the assets, and the assets will fall further and further into disrepair. That is part of the problem. The second part of the problem is a very serious issue that has arisen for the smaller, regional based nursing homes, and I have put that before the House in line with the amendments that are going forward. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: PAIRS
text: For the information of the previous speaker, I am a proud mother of three. Maybe he is not up to date--'-I am sure the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) is-but women have aspirations both for their children and for themselves. I will leave that matter as it is. As I was saying about the issue of the charge, the purpose of the amendments before us is to remove from this bill all reference to the accommodation charge and to remove the notion that people have to pay to get essential health care. The Labor Party do not support that notion. If we are unsuccessful in removing any reference to the charge, either in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, then Labor in government-we have made this commitment, and I will make it here again today-will get rid of this charge. Labor believe that if a person needs to go into a nursing home, they should be able to get that care without having to pay large sums of money. We have already seen the impact of these charges on people's willingness to go into nursing homes. They are seeking to remain in public hospitals. I imagine that, because of the level of care that they require, many people are going home when they should not be. One shudders to think the burden that that will impose on families. The other amendments before us today try to ensure that accommodation bonds apply only to people in hostels. We do not want to see a situation where people who move from a hostel to a nursing home have a choice, as the bill puts forward, about whether to pay an accommodation bond or a charge. We do not think that that choice should exist for Our view is that if you need nursing home care, that care should be available to you without charge. We want to make sure, through these amendments, that no bonds are chargeable in nursing homes. The next section of amendments makes it clear that we are trying to make sure that this government cannot introduce any other sort of charge. The Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) came in here today and explained how it was that he introduced these charges in the regulations on 6 November last year. I have to say that to us it seems the most convoluted way that any government could bring about a charge to one of the most vulnerable groups in the community. This government introduced a major piece of legislation into the House which we debated for some time last year. Then they found that the community outrage was so great they had to make some very rapid changes. The first of these changes was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and was announced on A Current Affair. The next day the minister had to pick up the ball and make what I would say were fairly rapid moves to put in place the capacity for the government to get rid of the accommodation bond and in its place have this charge. The section that they have used to bring about this charge would enable them to introduce any other charge in the future. So the amendments that are before us today seek to remove those sections so that we get rid of not only the accommodation charge that is in this bill we are currently debating but also the sections in the substantive act to make sure that this government and any future Liberal government cannot introduce any of these sorts of charges on very sick and frail Australians. The next part of the amendments goes to the refund of accommodation bonds. The House would be aware that when the Prime Minister went on A Current Affair, he said that people would no longer have to pay accommodation bonds because the government had realised that people would have to sell their homes to pay these bonds-a situation about which, not surprisingly, the compeople. munity was outraged. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: PAIRS
text: Barton) (1.35 p.m.)I rise to respond to the comments of the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), which effectively continue this line of scapegoating against our senior citizens. It started with the government's National Commission of Audit, which, from an economic rationalist point of view, very much put the senior citizens of this country into the debit side of the economist's ledger. An interesting article written by Professor John MCCallum, who is the Dean of the Faculty of Health at the University of Western Sydney, said: Since the arrival of the Howard Government in Canberra, the ageing of the Australian population is being more generally argued to make unsustainable demands on the health and social security system. In his article he talks about the arguments and concerns about the ageing population. He also talks about a report of the Economic Planning and Advisory Council which said that expenditure on health in 1990 represented about 8.4 per cent of gross domestic product and that, by the year 2051, it could represent about 11.1 per cent of gross domestic product. If that is supposed to be a cause for fear and trepidation when we are talking about a 2.7 per cent rise over 60 years, they should say it in that context. As Professor MCCallum says, those predictions for 60 years in the future are so frequently flawed. He points out that it is a fallacy to attribute, except to a trivial extent, the consequences of ageing to the total health care budget. He says that most health treatment is needed just before someone dies, but the consequence of medical science is that we are pushing back the age at which someone dies. When more and more people were dying at younger ages-below their 60s and 70s-the health costs were focused on debt incurred by those age groups. An average of five times more money is spent on someone immediately before they die. So the reason more money is required for health for our ageing population is simply that people are dying at later ages and more money is required at that final point of their lives. On the whole, the cost of sustaining senior citizens is really no more than normal up until that point of time. My father is 71, and I cannot remember the last time he went to a doctor. I know there are so many like him. Then there is me with a young family-you always seem to be a revolving door when you have young kids. It is simply wrong and fallacious to use scapegoating for this sort of measure. It is purely and simply an introduction of a userpays philosophy that falls on those who confront misfortune. Look at all the contributions that senior citizens have made to our society. Last night I mentioned the Depression, the Second World War and the post-war reconstruction. There is also a failure to have regard to what they now contribute to society. I understand, for instance, that the older community provide much more in unpaid child care than does the whole child-care system-that is, both the private and community based child-care systems. They contribute more by way of charities. If you go to any Meals on Wheels service, you will see that the participants are more likely to be senior citizens. They are certainly net contributors to society. They are not net takers from society. So to use them as scapegoats is simply wrong. As I have eIV-phasised, it is based on fallacious analysis. Just about all the speakers on the government side have had a scapegoating mentality. It is wrong and fallacious. The amendments that the shadow minister is moving are entirely appropriate because they recognise the responsibility of the community for looking after our senior citizens. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: PAIRS
text: Jagajaga) (1.40 p.m.)The opposition amendments go to ensuring that those people who unfortunately entered nursing homes from 1 October to 5 November last year have their accommodation bonds refunded. A few days after the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) went on A Current Affair and announced to the nation that he had done the biggest backflip of all time and was going to get rid of these accommodation bonds, it was announced that the government would have a person to help people get refunds of these accommodation bonds. In these amendments before us today, we are seeking to require the government to refund accommodation bonds. I want to tell the House of a story that is behind the opposition moving this amendment. I was at a community forum on the Central Coast which was attended by about 200 people at an RSL hall. A woman who was only in her 60s put up her hand and said, 'I want to tell you what happened to me when my husband and I moved up to the Central Coast from Sydney. We sold our home in Sydney and bought another home on the Central Coast.' Obviously they were looking forward to a long and happy retirement. Unfortunately, her husband had a massive stroke and had to be moved into a nursing home very quickly. Very unfortunately for the family, this happened during the period 1 October to 5 November last year. She had to sell the home that they had just bought on the Central Coast to make sure that her husband could get accommodation in a nursing home. He had had a massive stroke and was absolutely unable to stay at home, and she was unable to look after him. This is the reality of what this government is doing to the elderly and the not so elderly in this·country. People who desperately needed nursing home care were required to sell their homes to get this essential care. The lady had everybody in this hall in tears in response .to her story. Afterwards, I asked her, 'Have you approached the government to seek a refund for your accommodation bond?' She said, 'I didn't know that I was entitled to do that.' That is the reality of the situation that faces so many people: they are not informed of their rights; they are not told they have the capacity to seek a refund; and it is not required of the government, under the current legislation, to pay all these accommodation bonds back to the people who were so wrongly charged the bond for the bit over a month that it applied. In this amendment we are seeking to require the government to make a refund to people who most unfortunately had to pay these accommodation bonds. The amendments that flow from that are equally important. This lady had to sell her home. If we can require the government, through this amendment, to refund these accommodation bonds, we do not want to see some further adverse circumstances apply to this woman or to anybody else in her circumstance. In further amendments before the House today we are seeking to make sure that any money that is repaid to people who were required to pay these accommodation bonds is not counted as income under the Social Security Act. Another amendment before the House deals with the situation of those who had been assessed to go into a nursing home and who had sold their homes before 5 November in anticipation of having to pay an accommodation bond-because they were not to know that the Prime Minister was going to do this backflip. (Extension of time granted) We do not want to open up this system to fraud and therefore do not think it is fair for those people who sold their homes to have their social security payments reduced as a result of having the income that results from the sale of their homes. That is another very important amendment before the House today. As I said before, these are very significant changes that go to the heart of the difference between Labor and this government. As many people on the Labor side in this debate have made so clear, there is a fundamental difference between the way Labor sees access to nursing home care and the way this government sees it. When we started this debate nearly two years ago, we heard the minister at the time, and the Prime Minister in particular, making it clear that this' was just an accommodation choice-people could just decide to choose that between a hostel and nursing home care. Gradually this government has been forced by the elderly of this community and by their representatives to recognise that it was an unfair system that they put in place, that they had to get rid of the accommodation bond. Given the government's recognition of the need to get rid of the accommodation bond, I hope that they will support our amendments to ensure that people who were so unfortunately charged this accommodation bond will be refunded. What we would also like to see is the members of the government recognise that they have gone only a small part of the way, that what they have done is get rid of only the sheep's clothing, as the Australian Catholic Health Care Association so aptly put it. They have got rid of only the sheep's clothing; they have not got rid of the wolf that is still lying there waiting for people who need to go into nursing homes in this country. It will be the case, as a result of this government's changes, that people will have to pay very large sums of money if they need-not choose-nursing home care. If our amendments are unsuccessful, they will have to pay $4,380 every year, up to a maximum of five years, if they need nursing home care. It means that they will have to pay more than $20,000 for essential health care. That is what this Liberal Party stands for: making people pay more than $20,000 for essential health care. That is the bottom line. We do not agree with it. We move these amendments here today. We will continue to argue against this shift in the whole approach to essential health care in this country that this government is seeking to introduce-that is, people should pay for essential health care. That is what we are debating today. These amendments now before the House seek to remove the capacity of this government to charge people an accommodation charge for essential health care, for nursing home care. It is a very serious matter. It is of great concern to so many elderly Australians. In fact, in the Sydney Morning Herald today the national treasurer of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation said: Older people are getting angrier and angrier. This is really at the heart of it. She continued: Once again, this shows the Government didn't think it through. She said that confusion was increasing with each new change, and with each new change the fees just continue to rise. That is what the elderly have to look forward to in this country with a government that is committed to making sure that people pay and pay for nursing home care-for essential health care. That is at the heart of this bill, and that purpose of the amendments today-to get rid of the capacity for the government to continue to require people to pay for what we consider on this side of the House to be essential health care.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: PAIRS
text: I go back to a theme that I have raised previously in this House, which is to do with debt and capital. We have a government telling us about the debt we are going to pass on to our children and our grandchildren. It is a theme that has been run over and over again as a mask for a lot of social engineering. This is basically about social engineering. It is important that we equate debt with assets. We will pass on to our children debtthere is no doubt about that-but we will also pass on to our children assets. The question is: how do they balance? There is no doubt whatsoever that over the last 15 yearscertainly the 13 years of Labor governmentthe asset value increased at a much greater rate than the debt value. Anybody who drives to Canberra on the national highway which we have all shared the cost of will understand that, anybody who goes to an airport which we have all shared the cost of will understand that, and anybody who goes to our ports and looks at the infrastructure which we have all shared the cost of will understand that. These are being passed on to successive generations. We have all shared the cost of hospitals and nursing homes. These are infrastructure, not some luxury item that we choQse to have or not to have. These are things that are needed by a decent society to care for its own people. They incur a capital cost; that cost can be shared by generations via: intergenerational debt. Intergenerational assets and intergenerational debt are a valid and sensible form of sharing those costs. We are being told by this government that the generations that built the other assets are going to have to pay for their own care. Having shared the cost of the nation's assets, they are going to have to pay the cost of the assets to care for them. That is an enOJmous shift in both philosophy and in relationships, which is a fundamental shift in the way we have done things. We are making the aged is the who need nursing home care feel guilty. We heard the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) mention the figure of $40,000. What a disgraceful way to approach it. We have heard the term 'bed blockers' being used over and over. People who have the misfortune to need nursing home care are now seen to be culprits, like criminals-that it is their fault. People would love to die in their own beds peacefully with their family around them. That would be the choice for all of us, but some people are not so fortunate any more. We tried to put it in a form that, if you required nursing home care in your later years, it was unfortunate for you and we understood that but we shared the burden of it. We all took some responsibility. Now the government says, 'No, you take it yourself.' Just contrast that with what is happening today in terms of this new device we are now hearing a lot about-family· trusts. Think about it for a moment. If, five years before, you transferred your assets to a family trust which is controlled by somebody else who can give you money if they want to or do not want to, do you still pay up-front fees, do you still pay nursing home charges? No, you do not. We are saying now that the Aussie battler is going to have to transfer their family home to a family trust, then all of this will be irrelevant. What a shonky exercise is going on. On one hand this government is telling the aged people that all they have is a house and that they are going to have to pay but, on the other hand, the bulk of their front-bench is creating artificial vehicles to avoid both tax and those kinds of payments. That is what is happening. Why else would you have family trusts being created? We are now being told by representatives of the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) that this is a sensible thing to be doing. If you want to pass on your country. assets to your children, you put them in a family trust; the Aussie battler is being told to sell their house. You cannot give it to your kids because you are a squatter in a hospital, a bed blocker. But those who are clever it into a family trust instead so their kids the assets well in advance via that family trust. This government had better come clean as to its true agenda and who it actually represents .. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: PAIRS
text: I think we just need to remember why it is that we are debating this legislation and to make reference to what the Labor Party will do we are not successful in getting rid of this accommodation charge. It is the case that this government removed $500 million out of the aged care budget in 1996, and it sought to that money which had been allocated in the forward estimates to rebuild nursing homes. The idea of this government was to get that money out of the homes and the savings of the elderly of this country. We know the saga with the government denying day after day, week after week, 'No, it won't be the case that anybody will have to sell their family home.' I do not know how many times we were told that in here. The elderly of this country got so angry once they did have to start selling their family homes-and a number of people did have to sell their family home in the month that this accommodation bond did apply-that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) finally realised-the penny dropped-that it was not a very popular move. It was the biggest backdown we have seen in the last couple of years with the Prime Minister going on A Current Affair and saying, 'Yes, we finally realised that people would have to sell their family homes, so we'll get rid of the accommodation bond and we'll call it the accommodation charge.' The government still has the same objective-it still wants to get the money out of you somehow. That is really what this government is all about. This Liberal-National Party government took $500 million out of the aged care budget with the sole objective of making sure that it was made up somehow out of the pockets of the elderly of this If it was not going to be their homes, it was going to be the savings of their families. How many times has the Prime Minister come in here and said to me, 'Why don't they just ask their families whether they have got put a spare $4,380 every year?' I do not know get any battling family in Australia that has got a spare $4,380 that they can pull out of their pockets every year for five years to care for their elderly relatives. That is what this government wants to impose on this community. The whole purpose of the accommodation charge before us today is to make the elderly themselves pay for their essential health care. if That is what this government is all aboutstrip mining the assets of the elderly in this country, taking it out of their homes, taking it out of their savings. If they do not want to get use that option, as the Prime Minister says, 'Just go and ask your family for the $4,000.'

Speaker: Mr MCDOUGALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, would you inform the House of the government's broad approach regarding taxation treatment of trusts?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for the question. I think it is a very apposite question, given not only the report of the Taxation Office but also the matter of public importance that appears in the name of the newly rediscovered Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who is sort of trying to get back into the game after having been put in the shade a bit. He did not get much of the sort of conflict of interest actions, so he decided he wanted to get back into the game on this. The other important aspect of this is the report of the Commissioner of Taxation about the growth of trusts in Australia. One of the most interesting things, of course, is that the Commissioner of Taxation's report entirely relates to the period that the Labor Party was in office before the last election. So let it first be understood that trusts exploded under Labor. It is under Labor that trusts exploded, and in case the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or indeed any other members of the opposition are minded to say, 'What are you going to do about trusts?' I will reply, 'Why didn't you do something about them over the last 13 years?' No doubt the retort will come back, 'Oh, we were gonna do it in the 14th year.' Let me say that again: if there is any argument about the explosion of the uses of trusts in this country, if there is to be criticism of that, that is a damning indictment of the administrative performance of the former Labor government, because it was under Labor that trusts became a fast growing industry. It was under Labor, if there are any alleged abuses claimed in relation to trusts, that those abuses occurred. I want to say on behalf of the government that we naturally do not accept responsibility analyse for what occurred under Labor, but once again, as with the deficit, although we were not responsible, we will endeavour to fix problems and we will endeavour to fix abusTaxation es. We had to fix the deficit. The Leader of the Opposition left us with a $lOY2 billion deficit. We not only had to fix that deficit but had to face obstructive tactics from the Labor Party in our efforts to fix that deficit. Let me go further and make it very plain: our attitude in relation to any tax avoidance practices is that they will be addressed, and they will be addressed properly. I remind the parliament that only two nights ago the Senate passed some government legislation which prohibited trafficking in trust losses. That was an earnest of my government's determination to stamp out abuses, whether they occur under family trusts or whether they occur under any other area. May I repeat to the parliament, for the benefit particularly of the opposition, that the attitude of my government in relation to the taxation issue and in relation to family trusts is that the government parties in any taxation changes we make will not be acting in a manner which would seriously damage, or indeed damage at all, the small business community. I also want to make it clear that we will take, if necessary, action against the abuse of trusts. We have always taken action against the abuse of trusts, and that will be the attitude we will bring to the formulation of our taxation policy. But let there be no cant and humbug from the opposition: it was under the Labor Party that the use of trusts exploded. The report of the Commissioner of Taxation was not about our period in office. Trusts did not arrive on the Australian political scene on 2 March 1996; they burgeoned, they flourished, they grew like wildflowers under the Keating and the Hawke administrations, and any attempt to pretend otherwise is absolute humbug. Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Eden Monaro for his question. The Labor Party, the Democrats and the Independents have today rejected the government's bill which would have provided an exemption for small business from the unfair dismissal laws. In doing so, I think it is fair to say that the Labor Party have destroyed their credibility on the jobs issue. This was a measure which was aimed at providing opportunity and encouragement to the small business community to give people jobs. It has been estimated by small business itself that the passage of this legislation would have created 50,000 jobs.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: You can tell from the interjections on the other side that the Labor Party think this is a smart political game to play. The Labor Party think that if they do what the ACTU tells them this is somehow smart politics and this justifies their rejection of this proposal. Today the Labor Party have not rejected the government; they have rejected small business. You have rejected the 50,000 people who now will not get a job because of your weak policy. That is the consequence of this. The Labor Party would tell you that they are concerned about unemployment. When they get a chance to actually vote to give somebody a job, what do they do? They play politics and vote against a measure which by any reasonable standard was a fair and common sense proposal to give people a chance of a job. This issue has been around for some considerable time. The opposition say, 'Where is the evidence for the benefit of this particular proposal?' The evidence to justify this particular proposal is absolutely overwhelming. The small business community itself has made it clear that they would create more jobs. COSBOA, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, said that this measure, if passed, would create 50,000 jobs. The 50 major small business organisations which form the Small Business Coalition met in Canberra last month and they unanimously supported this proposal. The micro-business consultative group, which had on it people who were nominated by the Labor Party, unanimously supported this proposal. This is genuinely a very sad day, as the Labor Party has rejected the opportunity for 50,000 people to get a job. It destroys their credibility on jobs. It shows us that the hypocrisy of the Labor Party is now complete on this issue. Their credibility is in tatters. reveals again that when we need some nationalleadership and we look to the Leader of the Opposition we find a person unable to speak on behalf of the 50,000 people who would have got jobs from this change. Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question today is addressed to the Prime Minister, and it is a relevant question. Prime Minister, what are the benefits to all Australians of refonning the waterfront? Can you also advise the House of the restraints that have been put in the way of reform and who is responsible for this obstruction?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I think it is very instructive that, since the parliament resumed It this week, we have not had one question from the Labor Party about reform of the waterfront. We have had no question about the most important industrial relations issue facing Australia in 1998. There is a very simple reason for that and that is that the Labor Party, and particularly its leader, is scared stiff of the issue of reform of the Australian waterfront. The problem is that the Leader of the Opposition is bound to the Maritime Union of Australia. The Leader of the Opposition does not have the courage to stand up for the public interest against the bullying tactics of the Maritime Union of Australia. You never hear the Leader of the Opposition condemning the bullying tactics. You never hear the Leader of the Opposition speaking out in favour of reform in the national interest. All he does is say, 'Let's have another meeting.' When you were in government you had a meeting on taxation and that collapsed. You had a meeting on native title and that ended up with the 1993 native title mess that we now have the responsibility for sorting out. Waterfront strikes are nine times higher than the national average across all industries. Despite the fact that the Labor Party spent over $400 million of the Australian taxpayer's money on an absolutely useless, pointless and unproductive reform process for the Australian waterfront, the Australian waterfront has suffered scandalous levels of productivity and scandalous levels of uncompetitiveness and has been way behind the standards required to make this nation a truly competitive export country. Despite all of that, what is the answer of the Leader of the Opposition? The answer of the Leader of the Opposition is to march down the road, bound to John Coombs, the Secretary of the Maritime Union of Australia. This is what the Leader of the Opposition had to say, this is what the alternative Prime Minister had to say, on 2 February 1998 on 3AW: If you look at the record of the last eight years, after another those bad practices have fallen over. What an extraordinary sort of tick to give. What an extraordinary blank cheque to give to a union whose record of industrial thuggery is reaching its height in the way in which it is behaving in relation to Patricks at the present time. What do you hear from the Leader of the Opposition? Instead of getting up and condemning the Maritime Union of Australia in the public interest, instead of standing up for Australians and instead of standing up for the battlers of the trade union movement instead of the MUA, who are the elite of the trade union movement, what does the Leader of the Opposition do? The Leader of the Opposition puts his hand up and says, 'It's perfectly all right. Don't anybody worry, I will fix the waterfront. I will solve all of these problems. I will do what has not been done for the last 30 years. If I happen to get elected at the next election, I have a solution: I'll have a meeting.' That was the solution that Bob Hawke offered us; $420 million later we still had an unproductive waterfront, $420 million later we were still uncompetitive and $420 million later our crane rate was 18 a day versus 30, which is the average of our Asian competitors. The Labor Party, because it is bound hand and foot to the trade union movement of Australia, has no answer, no suggestion, no policy and no decent alternative on the waterfront because it is hopelessly bound, hand and foot, to the Maritime Union of Australia. Minister for Resources and Energy

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I respect the work of the member with regard to building on our export efforts, particularly from the Central Coast area of New South Wales. I am pleased to be able to inform the House that Seafreight, the official journal of Liner Shipping Services, the body representing Australian shipping interests, recently reported a survey of 750 businesses by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce on the waterfront. In answer to four questions, which I draw to the attention of the House, the following was the response: 'Do you believe the overall performance of the Sydney waterfront is unreliable?' Yes-81 per cent. 'Do you believe this waterfront performance is inhibiting your business growth?' Yes-81 per cent. 'Do you support the introduction of competition on the waterfront?' Yes-88 per cent. 'Do you support the federal government in pushing for waterfront reform, even if it meant disputation and disruption on the waterfront?' A resounding yes-90 per cent. That is the level of support. That is why Australian exporters' support for waterfront reform is not just comprehensive, not just widespread but absolutely overwhelming.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Clearly they are very sensitive about this issue-no questions, no policy, no commitment and no achievement in their 13 years of government with regard to waterfront reform. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
