Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Yes, he is a good bloke-a little bit marginal. I take my hat off to him because I heard the last 10 minutes or so of his speech on the Health Legislation Amendment (Health Care Agreements) Bill, and I have to say that he is a very brave man indeed. What he has not got in common with most of the other government members like the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou) and the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) who spoke on that bill, is that his margin is probably than the margin in Casey. Dr Wooldridge is okay; he is running off to Casey. But people like the member for Macquarie are left to carry the can. So I take my hat off to him for being brave enough-notwithstanding the fact that he has a margin less than that in Caseyto come in here and defend the indefensible. I note with great interest that the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is on the list for tomorrow. I do not often do it, but I take my hat off to the member for Paterson because I am sure-he is very marginal too, of course-he is going to come in here and criticise this government, as he should, because of the impact this government is having in the Hunter in terms of the health budget and health spending. He needs to come in here tomorrow, criticise his government and stand up for his electors for the first time since coming into this place. What the member for Paterson wants to do is to set the record straight about the outrageous claim of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that only 12 of the Hunter's 680 doctors do not bulk-bill at all. How crazy! There are at least that many in the member for Paterson's electorate who do not bulk-bill. Dr Wooldridge's criteria is this: if one doctor, out of sympathy, bulkbills one person in a given period, then he bulk-bills. If, in a 12-month period, a doctor bulk-bills one family desperately in needcold as he might be, he cannot help himself; he has to bulk-bill this family-then he goes into Dr Wooldridge's list of doctors who bulk-bill. How outrageous! The issue I want to raise tonight concerns regional airlines. Of course, being from the Hunter, I have a strong interest in it. The Federal Airports Corporation recently foreshadowed its intention in two areas which are going to adversely impact upon regional airlines. It proposes to dramatically increase landing charges for regional airlines at Kingsford Smith Airport, and it proposes to introduce new slot management arrangements which are going to make it increasingly difficult for regional operators to gain access to Kingsford Smith Airport. But now we know why, thanks to the Minister for Finance less and Administration (Mr Fahey). There are two ministers for finance: there is the minister for finance and there is John Fahey, member for Macarthur. Back in Macarthur, like many other members, he is under pressure over Sydney's second airport. His constituents do not want the planes flying over their homes. So what does he do? He does his own little newsletter, titled Airport News for Macarthur, by your local member, John Fahey, MP. He says in the newsletter: Of about 270,000 aircraft movements at Sydney Airport in 1996/97, 44% were regional and nonscheduled flights . . . If regional and other smaller flights such as these can be diverted to another airport, perhaps Bankstown, it may be that a second airport is not required for decades for come-it's a possibility would require detailed investigation. So here is the plan: you jack up the prices at Kingsford Smith for regional airlines. You don't have the guts to regulate to exclude them. You force them out to Bankstown-no need then for a second airport-and you save the minister for finance's bacon. I will tell you that people in rural and regional Australia will not take this latest attack. Rural and regional consumers are so dependent on these critical air services that the minister wants to exclude them to save his bacon in Macarthur. (Time expired) Child Care Aged Care

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Makin) (7.45 p.m.)Tonight I would like to speak about the Labor Party's scare campaign on aged care reforms, but firstly I would like to convey to the House a few facts in relation to long day child care and out of school hours care in my electorate of Makin. I have been meeting with providers of child care in my electorate, and they have been saying to me that their fees are actually lower now than they were before the changes. I have also been informed that the community based child-care centre has also lowered its fees in some cases. They are also saying to me that they are really angry with the scare campaign run by the Labor Party, because some parents, responding to this scare campaign, have made alternative arrangements for their children. So, while care providers have been lowering their fees in some cases, parents have withdrawn their children, which means higher vacancy rates and stress on management. The same case scenario applies for some of my out of school hours care providers, who are also really angry with the Labor Party for its scare campaign. The Labor Party has succeeded in frightening families enough that they. are making alternative arrangements, with the families not taking time out to investigate the true situation and being worried that, if the fees are not increasing at the moment, they will soon because of the changes. In relation to aged care, members from both sides of the House have highlighted the fact that that there are now empty beds in our nursing homes, when there were waiting lists before the Labor Party scare campaign. Where families have been frightened by the scare campaign mounted by the Labor Party, they are caring for their elderly relatives or spouse for a longer time at home. That impacts on HACC services and domiciliary care. It is very interesting that rumours that both the state and federal Liberal governments had cut funding completely to HACC services and domiciliary care were being put about in my electorate of Makin by various people. The truth of the matter is that domiciliary care services received an overall increase in budget allocation in 1997-98 in South Australia. The allocation rose from $24,220,000 to $25,855,000. The Northern Domiciliary Care service received an 8.6 per cent increase in funding. That was coupled with the one-off allocation of $1.76 million to the South Australian health commission. It is anticipated that a proportion of that funding will be allocated to the Northern Domiciliary Care service for the provision of basic equipment. Although Northern Domiciliary. Care, which covers my electorate, received an 8.6 per cent increase in funding-the greatest increase in the whole state of South Australia-demand for services has increased to an extent where services cannot keep up with demand. Guess why: the demand on services helping to keep those needing care at home has risen to extraordinary heights because of the Labor Party's scare campaign, directed at the elderly and at the families of those needing nursing home care. The Labor Party should be ashamed of the most ruthless, arrogant and unprincipled acts of campaigning in the history of Australia. If that is not enough, we also had the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) coming into this House in an attempt to initiate yet another scare campaign in relation to the PBS system. This campaign was directed at elderly residents already in nursing homes. On 22 October 1997, the member for Dobell, who has shadow responsibility for health, did not even know that it is the role of trained and dedicated nurses to supervise and dispense the medication requirements of residents in nursing homes. To further reiterate his complete lack of understanding of his portfolio, is worth pointing out that residents ofnursing homes are just that. They are not patients, as he called them. The member for Dobell thought it was expedient and politically astute to expand the Labor scare campaign to residents already living in nursing homes. Attempts by the' Labor Party to scare elderly Australians and their families, those who have built this country and who rely on their members of parliament .to make decisions in the best interests of the nation, can only be described as cowardly acts of 'political grandstanding at its' worse. We need to remember that for the fee of $21.10 per day those residents in care in nursing homes who are full pensioners-which is 67 'per cent of the nursing home resident population-receive three meals a day, laundry services, linen services, entertainment, electricity, water and 24-hour-a-day nursing. (Time expired). Brighton Training Camp

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to speak on the winding up of army recruitment training at Brighton Barracks-the Brighton Anny Camp-in southern Tasmania. The camp is in my electorate and has been a central training area for troops from all over Tasmania. It is situated 27 kilometres north of Hobart and occupies about 68 hectares of land just off the main hig;hway. Its location makes it an ideal venue for centralised training. The current course of recruits will be the last to be trained at Brighton, as the army has decided to transfer, training to the, mainland states and to introduce a longer induction period. This course will now be common for both full-time and part-time army recruits. The last recruit course will march out on a graduation parade next Sunday. These 38 recruits have been trained in occupational health and safety and workplace first aid, as well as traditional army skills such as navigation, bushcraft, rifle firing and the traditions of the Australian army. These recruits will join others in local units of the army reserve right around Tasmania. This is a sad time because Brighton has been the centre for recruit training since the tum of the century. Groups for the Boer War it and the First World War mustered near this camp. Many of the current camp buildings were constructed in World War II, and it is from this camp that all the soldiers from Tasmania were congregated before being sent to the mainland and overseas to join colleagues in theatres of war all over the world. The Tasmanian 2112 Battalion AIF, which served with distinction in the Middle East and the Pacific, underwent recruit training at the camp. Brighton was also the spot for the 18th National Service Battalion in the early 1950s. Since 1975, it has been the home of the 6th Training Group. The unit was responsible for recruit training, promotion courses and driving courses for the Tasmanian army reserve training. In the past, over 300 soldiers were trained there each year, with training conducted over a series of camps spread throughout this period. Now promotion courses and recruit training will no longer be available in Tasmania. The army at Brighton has been a source of employment for locals, and generates income for suppliers and service businesses in the district and Hobart. Its closure will be a significant loss to the suburb and the region of Brighton. With this, and the loss of recruiting staff around Tasmania, it will mean many Tasmanians are likely to miss out on training or will feel constrained to offer their services as reservists. It is disappointing that yet another federal government service is being closed in Tasmania. There will be many memories tied up in the Brighton camp, and I hope that they are treated with respect whatever the future holds for this site because, as I said, most Tasmanians who' served overseas in the AIF have been through this camp. I pay tribute to all those who have been involved in the camp during its operations and hope that their contributions will be recognised as being of a great value to the state of Tasmania. National Party

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Last night we had a very pleasant function with Doug Anthony, which you, Mr Speaker, attended, and it brought to my mind the very great achievements of the government of that period. I was recently at the gulf towns of Normanton and Karumba, and the wonderful beef road that was built from Cloncurry up to the Port of Normanton and then on to the more modern port of Karumba has been a boon that has enabled that little port to now put through $1,000 million worth of product every year, starting the year after next. It already doing about $200 million or $300 million worth of product now. It gives me no joy to recount that, whilst the airstrip at Normanton was sealed by .the then government, the airstrip at Karumba has not been sealed, and these responsibilities are now the responsibilities of local government. Fifteen years of Labor governments has shown a total neglect of all regional areas of Australia, it is something that this government must take cognisance of and reverse. We also built the massive Snowy Mountains Authority projects mostly affecting New South Wales cities, and little tiny townships such as Deniliquin, Griffith and Hay became flourishing inland cities of which every person in this country can be very proud. The Ord Scheme at the top of Western Australia is now turning a very handsome profit for this nation in spite of a number of years of difficulty. I am very proud to say that in Queensland where we had a National Party government as well as a federal National Party which was very active and aggressive in the federal government of the day, we built the Bundaberg Dam, the Kinchant Dam, the Bjelke-Petersen Dam, the Burdekin Falls Dam, the Emerald Dam and the Proserpine Dam. They were massive achievements, and I deeply regret that the representative of the Labor Party here thinks this is funny. Mr Kelvin Thomson interjecting

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Those achievements created 100,000 jobs in Queensland, and those dams are responsible for bringing well over $1,000 million per year into the economy of Queensland. Maybe closer to $2,000 million per year has been created by the building of those dams. In those 20 glorious years that we, if not reigned supreme, most certainly had a very substantial say in the government of Australia, we were able to achieve great things, and it is with deep regret that, in the 15 years since the waning of the National Party's powers, there has not been a single, solitary dam undertaken in Queensland-not one. As I have pointed out in the House previously and I will do so again this evening, you can get in an aeroplane and fly from Townsis ville all the way to Broome, look out either side of that aircraft and not see a single sign of human habitation, and yet you have just flown over three-quarters of this nation's water assets and more than half of the nation's arable land. There is nothing down there at all. I would urge, in the strongest possible manner, this House to look at what should be the next dam scheme in Australia, and which is the Hell Gates dam on the Burdekin River-the third biggest river in Australia. That scheme, according to the economic analysts-outside economic analysts, I might add, as well as from the Queensland government-will produce $720 million of revenue a year for the Australian nation for an outlay of $420 million. We do not even need $420 million. All we need is somewhere between $50 million and $75 million out of a federation fund or some other government instrumentality or department and we can proceed to return to this country $720 million a year of which, in all probability, $240 million will come to this government every single year by way of taxation. If any business person had a proposition put to them that, for an outlay of some, let us say, $60 million, you can show an annual return of $240 million, that would be a magnificent return on invested capital. I urge in the strongest possible way that this House consider what is genuine job creation and progress for this nation. Question resolved in the affirmative. House adjourned at 7.59 p.m. NA The following notices were given: Mrs Bailey to move: That this House: (1) expresses its concern at the number of bank branches which have been closed in both rural and outer suburban areas; (2) calls on the major banks to honour their responsibility to provide services to their customers and the community as well as delivering dividends to their shareholders; (3) further calls on the major banks to adopt a moratorium on any further planned branch closures until such time that alternative services are made available to their customers and that their customers are educated in electronic banking practices; (4) endorses the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration's investigation into the feasibility of the major banks providing a combined banking kiosk or agency capable of delivering full banking facilities in areas where no bank exists because of branch closure; (5) urges the Government to ensure that departments and agencies are able to utilise alternative banking arrangements such as regional banks, building societies or credit unions where applicable; and (6) notes and supports the Government's financial support of the Credit Care program in rural areas which has provided the means to re-establish financial services through regional banks, credit co-ops and building societies in areas where the major banks have withdrawn services. Dr Lawrence to move: That the House: (1) notes the visit of Pope John Paul n to Nigeria between 21 and 23 March 1998 and his call to Nigerians to rid their society of everything offends the dignity of the human person or violates human rights; (2) notes reports from Amnesty International that arrests and beatings of human rights activists have shamelessly continued right up until the Pope's visit including the arrests and beatings of two defence lawyers who defended Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni leaders before their execution in November 1995; (3) further notes that Amnesty International has reported that since 1983, when the military overthrew the elected. civilian government, nearly 90 persons have been executed following grossly unfair and politically motivated trials; (4) expresses serious concern at the grossly unfair and secret treason trial by Special Military Tribunal of 26 persons including the Deputy Head of State to Nigeria, General Oladipo Diya, who all face possible execution; (5) calls on the Australian Government to urgently meet with representatives of the Nigerian Government to (a) press the Nigerian Government to release immediately and unconditionally all prisoners of conscience and put an . immediate end to repeated human rights violations and (b) urge the Nigerian Government not to impose death sentences in the trial beginning on 14 February 1998 of General Oladipo Diya and 25 others. Delegation to the General Assembly of the Bureau of International Expositions (Question No. 2612) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Further to the answer to question No. 2506. has the Government directly or through servants or agents received representations from foreign Governments. instrumentalities or agencies requesting it to reverse its decision not to participate in Expo 98 in Lisbon; if so, what was the nature of each representation. Mr Moore--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: No. Delegation to the General Assembly of the Bureau of International Expositions (Question No. 2613) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Further to the answer to question No. 2507, why did the Government reverse its original decision not to participate in Expo 2000 in Hanover. Mr Moore--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The original decision was taken at a time when the Government's priority was to repair the fiscal situation it inherited. In December 1997 the Premier of Queensland offered to arrange a State! Territory contribution of $8.5 million towards participation. The Government agreed to match this contribution. Residential Aged Care: Government Responsibility (Question No. 2623) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) What is the federal Government's responsibility with respect to the administration of accommodation and other support services for persons with disabilities including the provision of alternative services for younger persons residing in residential aged care. (2) Is there an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States regarding the matter referred to in part (1); if so, (a) when was it entered into, (b) what is its duration and (c) what is the nature of the agreement. Mr Warwick Smith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) None. The State and Territory Governments have full responsibility for the administration of accommodation and other support services for people with disabilities. The Commonwealth has responsibility for the administration of employment services, while responsibility for advocacy services is shared. Young people who meet the criteria can enter Commonwealth aged care nursing homes, but only as a last resort when no other option exists. (2) Yes, the Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement. (a) 30 July 1991. (b) Five years from 1 July 1992. From 30 June 1997, the funding arrangements have continued on a month by month basis while negotiations on a new multilateral agreement continue. (c) The first Agreement provided for: - the rationalisation of government responsibility for the provision of disability support services, so that it is clear which level of Government is responsible for particular types of services. - establishment of a national legislative framework, with each State and Territory passing legislation for the provision of disability services in accordance with the principles and objectives pursuant to the Commonwealth Disability Services Act 1986; and - the level of funding to be provided by the Commonwealth to State and Territory Governments. Department of Transport and Regional Development: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry Grants (Question No. 2649) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Has the Minister or the Minister's Department provided grants to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) or bodies related to the ACCI since 2 March 1996; if so (a) in each case (i) what was the nature of the grant and (ii) for what purposes was it provided and (b) what total sum was provided. (2) To what boards, committees or other bodies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility have (a) Mr Mark Patterson, the chief executive of ACCI, or (b) other officers or staff of the ACCI been appointed since 2 March 1996. (3) What sums has the Commonwealth paid in sitting fees, board fees, travel costs and related expenses with respect to each appointment referred to in part (2). Mr Vaile--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. (2) None. (3) Not applicable. Kirribilli House and The Lodge: Prime Minister in Residence (Question No. 2706) Mrs Crosio asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 March 1998: How many days has he spent in residence at (a) Kirribilli House and (b) The Lodge since 2 March 1996. .

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: From 2 March 1996 to and including 14 March 1998 I spent 320 nights at Kirribilli House, 246 nights at The Lodge and 177 nights at other locations.
